snippet: In interviews, even Americans who deplore Donald J. Trump’s call to ban Muslim immigrants are more fearful after the rampage in California.
abstract: Interviews with American voters, even those who do not support Republican presidential candidate Donald J Trump and deplore his call to ban Muslim immigrants, make clear that they are more fearful now--after massacre in California--than at any time since Sept 11 terrorist attacks; Trump's support continues to rise, despite majority of voters who disapprove of his plan.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Yamiche Alcindor, Christina Capecchi, Ashley Parker, Jeremy W. Peters, Rebecca Fairley Raney and John Surico.

lead_paragraph: In interviews, even Americans who deplore Donald J. Trump’s call to ban Muslim immigrants are more fearful after the rampage in California.

headline.main: Attack Spurs New Chapter in History of Dread in the U.S.
headline.print_headline: New Chapter in the History of U.S. Dread

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
